instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.MEMVTT_EN_L: What is MEMVTT_EN_L? MEMVTT_EN_L is a signal that enables memory VTT voltage power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]Another one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Cpu Gets Warm No fan Spin
threads.message: Whats up guys just shoot me quick, green light on charger no liquid damage cpu gets warm, no fan spin 5vs0 3v3s0 is present no known shorts to ground let me guess dead graphics chip should i send to the donor gods or does it have a chance for life again?

threads.title: [SOLVED]Another one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Cpu Gets Warm No fan Spin
threads.message: No fan spin means usually <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is not present, check it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Another one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Cpu Gets Warm No fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 26979"]No fan spin means usually <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> is not present, check it.[/QUOTE]

100% right Duke 0.050 v at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>. I did a compare with a good working board at <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> i also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and have the same result i'm a little confused because the readings are not too far off. threads.title: [SOLVED]Another one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Cpu Gets Warm No fan Spin
threads.message: Measure all rails, one will be missing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Another one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Cpu Gets Warm No fan Spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27019"]Measure all rails, one will be missing. [/QUOTE]

Thanks for the advice Duke! Mark this one as solved i was missing a rail just as you said. Turns out i was missing <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> which comes from <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>, that was missing <SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> signal that comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q3250</TRANSISTOR> pin 5. Turns out the <SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN_L</SIGNAL> signal was high due to <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> not opening the source to drain replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR> and bingo fan spin again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]Another one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Cpu Gets Warm No fan Spin
threads.message: Since when does this happen for any reason other than <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> missing? I'm jealous!!
